reviews.author: Veronica Chow
reviews.title: Easy course for ICT students
reviews.comment_content:
Covers basic VBA language and a little more advanced programming logic, including objects in object-oriented programming and recursion. ICT students / those who have programming experience can definitely get an A range. A lot of ICT students take this course cause it's so easy for them. However, others may need to spend more time understanding programming concepts, so the grade distribution is rather unfair on some levels. Remember to ask for help.
I studied ICT as an elective for DSE, and since my then teacher made us write programs from scratch, I'm already very familiar with programming language and logic. Besides the first 2-3 lectures, I skipped all the others and still got an A.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rossiter is a very nice professor with great sense of humour. He makes sure the class can follow by talking slowly and using simple words, cause he knows programming can seem very difficult for beginners. He's very willing to answer your questions after lectures. It's always fun to attend his lectures.
Gibson was my TA for the lab sessions. He also talks through the labs in moderate speed and makes sure we can follow. Since labs only last for 1-2 hours, if you can't follow, you can always ask for help anytime without difficulty.
Rossiter says that it's necessary to buy his book, but I think it's optional. His lecture PowerPoints are definitely enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
- 7 labs (2 ungraded)
- 1 mid-term
- 1 final

There are labs every week or so to imply what's learnt during lectures. Nothing counts attendance (besides mid-term & final, of course), so you can stay at home and complete what's needed.
I could finish some lab sessions on my own, but I still attend all labs in case I've missed something important. Labs are the easiest way to get your grades higher. I got full marks for all labs, and the mean is usually 90-100 / 100. You can always ask for help from your friends who have finished their labs.
Mid-term and final are both open-book, so the tricky part is the logic. I recommend writing your own set of notes to keep things neat and easy to navigate during exams. I wrote within 20 A4 pages, which is much easier to navigate than those who brought the whole book + every single lab printout.
Rossiter is very flexible on mid-term and final grades. There are 3 ways to incoperate them into your final grade:
1) mid-term only
2) final only
3) some mid-term, some final (I forgot the exact percentage)
The method with the highest score is taken. Definitely helps you to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Very manageable workload. The only assignments are the labs, and since you can always ask for help when you feel stuck / have no time to finish them, it's really easy to handle.

reviews.author: Johnson162
reviews.comment_content: The course first covers basic things in Excel, and then Macro, and then real VBA programming. The things taught at the very beginning are quite easy but it got more difficult as the class moved on. It is not as easy as described by the majority of opinion here.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is a very fun professor and able to create a nice learning environment. He could get serious sometimes though, like he would feel annoyed if you keep talking. Once I saw him directly ask students to stop talking. And he also didn't like ring tones in class, which he would talk about in the very first lesson. Some people his pace is too slow, while I think it's a bit faster than I can handle well.
reviews.comment_grading: If you don't have computing background and not talented in programming, it can be difficult. For me, at the very beginning the others think the things are super easy while I thought was fair; as the others thought the materials taught are of fair difficulty I already felt so tired reading the lines of code. Becoz of lazy reasons I didn't attend the lectures since mid term. Before exam I spent four WHOLE day doing revision and ended up with B+.
reviews.comment_workload: There are lab works, around six throughout the semester. From my observation, students' performance in this course has a very large dispersion, like somebody think the lab work is so easy while some think it's soooo difficult. But if you go to the lab session you can finish the work without understanding it haha, see what you choose.

reviews.author: asdfasdfasdfasd
reviews.title: Good Grade Course only if you have good programming skills
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite rich. My first programming language is not Excel VBA, but the programming concepts are very similar. I think the hardest thing for most of the people is just the weird syntax of Excel VBA, recursion, object-oriented programming and the difference between "procedure" and "function". So if you don't know programming, don't register this course unless you are a diligent person and willing to figure out many new concepts or have a friend who knows programming so you can seek help anytime. If you know programming and just want to have some good grade yet low workload course, this will be your best choice without any regrets. Trust me :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rossiter David is really good at teaching and drawing your attention. He always starts lessons with "OK, Let's begin!!!" and often use funny metaphor eg "Your grandma wants to know what the program is doing!" or "Your grandma is so exciting that she is jumping up and down!!" Above are just some bullshit but I'm really impressed, sorry :)
But if you are confused by the content of lessons, you can drop down questions and ask him after class. He is very patient and willing to answer all of your questions from my own experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
Don't know much about the grading scheme or cutting scores. COMP1022Q uses two grading scheme. The overall idea is that if you performed better in exam when comparing with midterm, they will put lower weights on the previous midterm and more weights on the final exam. There's no point for you to remember the exact percentage for two grading scheme but just understand what's the point of having two grading scheme. This is also very important for COMP1022Q. This course often requires you to understand the program instead of just reading and writing some meaningless codes.

Here's my result, not showing off but just would like to provide some reference.
Studied ICT and got 5* in DSE
Lab full mark
Midterm 97
Final 88
Bonus mark 8
Total: 95/100
Overall A+
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite low. The only workload is just the 5 sets of assignment. You can finish it by yourself, with friends or seek help from your TA. TA will help you do the rest if the you have spent them too much time or if you are a girl with a good-looking face :). And then they will be very happy to teach you hand by hand. I'm a boy and this is HKUST. 淡淡的哀傷 :')

reviews.author: Small_Potato
reviews.title: Simple course with a very wide A range
reviews.comment_content:
Simple programming logic, how to use Excel functions and write basic VBA code. It is a popular course among students with no background in programming, as the codes written are very simple and even looks like English paragraphs. You learn basic stuff like If-Else arguments and For-To-Step loops, and some recursion. Not that difficult actually, if you try understanding the codes on your own instead of blindly following the instructions.

You can get good grades easily if you already have some basic understanding in programming, but if you have that knowledge and want a course with a difficulty more suitable, then go for COMP1021 to learn about Python. However, if you want a definite A+, stay here and enjoy a relaxing course haha :o)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rossiter is a great teacher. Funny and lively teaching which makes it difficult to fall asleep in lesson albeit the late lesson time. He asks review questions by choosing random people (on the basis of colour of clothes or the row you are sitting in), and if you answer it correctly, you get an additional 0.4 mark to your overall score. Sometimes he makes jokes like "Oh your grandma wants to know how this code works, but your explanation was bad so your grandma is now very sad. :(" His explanation is very clear and easy to follow and he is a very helpful instructor.

The lab instructor was also very helpful even though his pace of teaching was pretty slow, possibly due to the number of students who have no programming background in this course. You can jump ahead of the progress and leave whenever you want.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy:
Lab 40% (8% x 5)
Participation: +0.4 to overall score for each correct attempt

If your midterm mark is higher than finals mark then
Midterm 20%
Finals 40%

Otherwise
Midterm 0%
Finals 60%

Lab full marks
Midterm above mean 1.38 SD
Finals above mean 1.64 SD
Participation +1.2 marks to overall score
Grade: A+

Apparently if you get >93% overall you get A+ already. Absolutely lenient grading. Seriously, how wide is the A range???

Also for both midterm and finals, you can bring in any notes you wants. Some people may print all of the lecture notes and buy the textbook and bring them all to the exam hall, while some may just bring a short piece of hand-made notes.

If you have good logic and are skillful in algorithms, I think the questions will not be too difficult. Some of the questions may require quite a lot of mental exertion though.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework, and the lab is taught step by step in the lesson. You can complete your lab easily on your own. If you don't understand, as long as you pay attention in lesson, you can easily complete the lab. The workload is super light. Try to attend the lessons for a chance to answer Rossiter's review questions and gain bonus points.

reviews.author: Otaku
reviews.title: Excellent introductory course
reviews.comment_content: The course introduces fundamentals of programming. Procedural programming are covered. Some object oriented programming principles are covered but not in depth.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Rossiter's teaching is vivid and on point. He made tricky concepts easy to understand with a lot of examples and questions during classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very lenient, as expected from a year 1 introductory courses. The graded course content consists of 3 components, namely, lab work, an optional mid term exam, and a final exam.

It is suspected that if one can get full credits in all the programming assignments (i.e. lab submittions) and do moderately well in the written examinations, a good grade can be received.

The performance of the mid-term and the final examination is generally well. The expected value of marks is about 70 and 60 respective. Since the examinations are open book, a lot of answers could be looked up in notes easily if one has reviewed them beforehand. Therefore, it is expected that one should perform well in the two papers.
reviews.comment_workload: About one lab (programming assignment) per week and no homework. The lab pages are so detailed that one should have no trouble figuring out the missing part in the skeleton code. Besides lab works, which requires less that 2 hours to complete, one only have to study hard for the written examinations. Possibly the least workload course in HKUST.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_grading:
Things being assessed:
labs
midterm(optional)
final exam
bonus
(both midterm and exam are open book)
labs:
Marking guideline will be given before you submit your lab
If you check everything carefully, you can get full mark
(the TA will teach you step-by-step in the lab session)

mid-term exam:
rather easy
If you listen to him in class (mentioning some tricky part in Excel), probably will get 90% or above
You can skip the midterm, all in final is an option given
(in my opinion, final exam is much more difficult, and the midterm can actually help you get higher mark if you attend it)

Final:
quite hard, some questions consist of something that is not even mentioned in the textbook

Bonus:
If you are lucky enough, you will be called in class to answer his question. If you know the answers, for each answer you get, you can have an extra of 0.4% added to your final grade calculation

Me:
labs all100%
midterm 100%
final 87%
bonus 3 times
overall, A+

reviews.author: wtcheng
reviews.comment_content:
The course is basically about the Excel features and programming by using VBA.

There is a course book.The professor will give a lot of working examples to illustrate the content. There would be lecture questions in every lecture and the professor would randomly pick students to answer the questions. All materials in the lecture would be uploaded on the web.

The content in the lecture is generally easy to understand. Although the content is easy to understand, students without programming background would find a bit hard to think of the answer in the examination. The professor also said that some students need time to get used to this kind of thinking.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor always ask questions to allow us to take an active role in the class. He always make jokes in the lectures and making the lectures a funny one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs * 5 - 40%/0%
Midterm Exam - 20%
Final Exam - 40%/60%
Bonus lecture marks (an extra 0.4% added to your end of semester final mark if answer the questions in the lecture correctly)

The "disappearing" midterm mark:
If using your midterm mark gives you a higher end-of-semester mark, then we will automatically include your midterm mark. In this situation your marks distribution is shown two slides ago: Midterm 20%, Lab projects 40%, Final exam 40%
If using your midterm mark gives you a lower end-of-semester mark, then we will automatically exclude your midterm mark. In this situation your marks distribution will be: Midterm 0%, Lab projects 40%, Final exam 60%

Midterm below mean
Lab full mark
Final above mean 0.5 SD
reviews.comment_workload: There is a lab once a week. It is pretty easy if you understand the content in the lecture. You can also score full mark if you attend the lab sessions and follow what the TAs do.

reviews.author: Orange_C

But if you are a good student you may find the materials a little bit too easy, so for those who like challenges, they should take 1021 OR 1022P instead.
reviews.comment_teaching: Rossiter is really a nice professor, he gives interesting lectures and replies email very quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading systems, Lab40/Mid20/Final40 or Lab40/Final60. It seems a range is 20% so if you work hard and go to all the lectures and read the notes before exams, it will be easy to get good grades

Btw the exam mean is around 75 for Mid and 65 for final with SD around 15.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is nearly zero. There are six hand in labs. You don't really need to go to the lab, you just do it yourself and hand in. But if you go, the TA will basically help you with anything you are not clear about so it is quite easy to get 100(mean is often around 95 for labs)

reviews.author: Cathleen
reviews.title: Good professor & course
reviews.comment_content:
This course is totally focused on the Microsoft Excel
program, which is part of the Microsoft Office group

There are 3 introductory courses run by the CSE
department that anyone can join
• Each of them teaches computer programming and
related techniques, but there are some differences:
• COMP1021 Introduction to Computer Science
– Teaches the Python programming language, which is a
really good language for learning programming
– It looks at some areas of computer science (CS) that
the other two courses don’t look at, to get a better
appreciation of CS

• COMP1022P Introduction to Computing with Java
– A lot of computer languages think about things as objects
– This course focusses on teaching the concept
of objects and how they interact using the Java
programming language

• COMP1022Q Introduction to Computing
with Excel VBA
– This course is totally focused on the Microsoft Excel
program, which is part of the Microsoft Office group
– First, students learn how to use Excel (without
programming), then they learn how to program it

The notes will be released on the web site before
the lecture, so you have time to download (and
print them if you like) and bring them to class

On successful completion of this course,
students are expected to be able to:
1. Manipulate and visualize data using
Microsoft Excel
2. Program using the VBA language within
Microsoft Excel to build effective
solutions to problems

Sometimes we’ll ask questions during the lecture
sessions
• If you answer correctly, you’ll get an extra 0.4%
added to your end of semester final mark
• (This is simply added on top of the other marks)

Exams Quite hard.

If using your midterm mark gives you a lower end-ofsemester

reviews.comment_teaching:
There are some bonus questions during lessons. Some bonus points are added if you answer them correctly.
No attendance but you should not skip lab sessions. Lab sessions will teach you to finish the lab step by step. It is useful for exams. You may ask questions and TA will give you hints.
reviews.comment_grading: Good. Many classmates get B range or above. Mean of the exam are around 6x and SD is around 17 marks.

With the help of VBA, statistical reports and analysis can be automatically generated simply by writing VBA codes. This course can be a good starting point to learn VBA.

reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not heavy. Although there are assignments every two weeks if I remember correctly, if fact, the assignment wasn't difficult at all. The lab materials are very useful when it comes to comprehending the basic concept of VBA.

reviews.author: Sunny Ng
reviews.title: The best introductory computing course you can find.
reviews.comment_content:
The syllabus includes:
- An introduction to Excel
- Simple Cell Formulas
- Basic Excel VBA Programming
- Making decisions with VBA
- VBA Loops
- GUI Handling
- Functions, Subroutines
- Cell Functions in VBA
- Object-Oriented programming
- Recursion
- Arrays

You may not know what I'm talking about when you look at the list, but I can assure you that the above topics will be taught at an introductory level and you will not find it way too challenging. If you are really interested, ask your best friend - google.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It has been a pleasure to be one of David's students.

Before this course, I had no interest in computing at all. I would fear computer codes as I see them as boring and complicated stuff. However, David made computing look very interesting (and easy) for me.

David is definitely one of the best lecturers you can possibly meet in this institute. His English is, of course, very good and he speaks fluently throughout the entire lecture. You can tell that he knows the course content extremely well as if he had been teaching this course since he was born. His classes are interactive and well-planned. He is also a funny teacher with a special sense of humor.

I would also like to talk about the lab instructors. They have been really helpful and they will be more than willing to  I am pretty sure they played a very important role in helping me learn.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is shown below:
36% assignments × 3
24% mid-term exam
40% final exam (includes everything)

It is relatively easy to get a decent grade in this course. Having almost no background knowledge in computing and excel, I found the course pretty easy to be dealt with.

The 3 assignments are not difficult. You will be able to find help from the lecturer and lab instructors. During the lectures, the lecturer will explain some tips for the assignments. During lab sessions, the instructor will assist you in constructing your assignments step-by-step. If you attend all lab sessions, you will have about 80% of the assignments completed! The rest can be handled relatively easily with some straight-forward thinking.

The exams are not hard as well. If you understand the stuff the lecturer mentions or if you study the notes well enough, you will find yourself being awarded a grade within the A range. The key in excelling is understanding, not memorizing.
reviews.comment_workload:
Basically, the workload is rather light and you will have plenty of time left for other courses (and also other stuff in life).

You have 3 assignments throughout the 13 weeks. If you attend all the lab sessions, you will only need to spend around 2 extra hours on each assignment.

The mid-term and final exams require some studying. But as the exams are open book, no memorization will be required. Just make sure you understand the stuff before you enter the exam hall. The stuff is not hard to understand and you will end up spending less time preparing for this course compared to many others in general.

reviews.author: ChingChongCheng
reviews.title: Very Good Grade, Would Recommend to Everyone
reviews.comment_content:
Content is relatively simple, very suitable for everyone who has never taken any Excel related courses before.

I would just like to note that I have never used Excel before I took the course, and still found it relatively easy and straightforward; it is mostly about logical thinking!

First 40% of the course is based on Excel basics, i.e. formula and other basic functions; then the next 60% is all about VBA, which is really useful in the future workplace (also why I have decided to take the course)

All of the topics:
1. Starting to use excel
2. Cell formatting
3. More on Cell reference
4. Excel table
5. Cell formula basics
a. Sum, average, St Dev., Max, Min, RANK, COUNTIF
6. Making decisions
7. Worksheet
8. Introduction to VBA
9. First Look at VBA
10. Look Up Techniques (VLOOKUP & HLOOKUP)
11. Getting started with VBA
12. Handling Cell Formula Errors
13. VBA Macros
14. Using Mod for Patterns
15. VBA Basics
16. Referring to Cells in VBA
17. Making decisions with VBA
18. Introduction to Looping
19. Types of variables in VBA
20. Using for loops
21. More on For Loops
22. GUI Control
23. Functions & Subroutines
24. Using Set Keyword
25. More on Variables
26. Currently Selected Cell
27. Random Number
28. For Each Loop
29. Colour, Objects & Shapes
30. Cell Functions in VBA
31. Custom Functions
32. Objects
33. Array
34. Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good, no attendance is necessary, so if you already know Excel VBA this course is literally 0 workload for you.

David is hilarious himself, which made me go to class even though I don't really listen half the time (the lecture notes were super easy to understand, and if you don't understand anything you can always watch the lecture videos).

*** Just want to point out again that I have never taken any Excel related courses and still found the notes and what he says relatively straightforward.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading, in my opinion is fair enough. I have heard from everyone else that this is a very good grade course, around 30%+ A range I will say. I am sorry that I have forgotten about the proportion of grades but I remember that the grade is made up of 3 components:

1) Assignments (x3)
2) Mid Term
3) Final

At the beginning of semester, they also gave us a choice to vote on if you did really badly in the mid term, you can disregard it and the grade will based on Assignment and Final.

My Grade:
Assignments
Final mark for all 3 was 100 (mean was around 94-95)

Mid term
Final mark was 88 (Mean around 70, I was 0.9x SD above mean)

Final
Final mark was 90 (Mean around 75, again, around 0.99 SD above mean)

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The only workload, apart from revision (which is minimal because all mid terms and finals are open book), is doing the 3 assignments. First one is non-VBA, the other two were VBA related.

Both the second and third one took quite a bit of time for me as I was not very good at VBA. However, that wasn't a problem because 75% of the assignments are completed during labs, so I would encourage you to go to the labs even though you don't care about the lectures. Furthermore, you can always get the TA to help you with your assignments, just make sure you are really careful when writing your codes.

reviews.comment_grading:
Two Grading Systems exist.
Professor will tell us to vote on the Canvas.
Choice 1:
If using your midterm mark gives you a higher end-of-semester mark, then we will automatically include your midterm mark. In this situation your marks distribution is: Midterm 30%, Assignment 1 15%, Assignment 2 15%, Final exam 40%.
Choice 2:
If using your midterm mark gives you a lower end-of-semester mark, then we will automatically exclude your midterm mark. In this situation your marks distribution will be: Midterm 0%, Assignment 1 15%, Assignment 2 15%, Final exam 70%.
Finally it is optional so professor will choose the one we have a higher percentage to be our final score and count the grade.

My score:
Assignment 1: 95/100
Assignment 2: 95/100
Mid-term: 80/100
Final: 91/100
Finally A

Someone has told me that this score can be A+ in Fall Sem so I do not is it really good grade or not.
reviews.comment_workload:

reviews.author: wwpy
reviews.title: The god of good grade!!!
reviews.comment_content: This is a pretty useful course where you can learn some excel VBA functions that may bring more convenience to you in the future. The main topics covered are basic excel functions (like cell referencing, vlookup, hlookup, countif), VBA programming concepts (subroutines, objects, recursion) and introduction of excel workbook, worksheet and modules. The level of difficulty is for beginners who have little to no programming background, so do not expect to learn anything advanced.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor just reads from the powerpoint slides, and there is not much additional information aside from the concepts and examples covered in the course materials. Moreover, attendance is not taken so it is your decision whether or not to attend the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: My two friends and I who have studied ICT in secondary school got A+, scoring about 96% on both midterm and final (that is equivalent to getting two sub-questions wrong). Two other classmates who had no ICT background got A- and B+ respectively. Basically, if you have learnt basic coding and excel functions there should be no difficulty in getting a good grade. Even if you have not touched these concepts in the past, they are pretty straight-forward and not difficult to understand.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite small, with only two open book exams and weekly lab sessions. It is easy to get full marks in the lab sessions as long as you attend them because there are step-by-step instructions you can follow and you can ask the TAs anytime if you are stuck. If you cannot attend the labs, you can also hand in the file by e-mail.

reviews.author: Pang.
reviews.comment_content:
Divided into Excel and VBA.
Excel should be easy as students have been using them since primary school. Basically the Excel part focuses on teaching how to use the cell functions, e.g. IF(), AVERAGE(), VLOOKUP() etc.

VBA (Visual Basic for Applications) is a language I personally dislike as its style and syntax is significantly different from the more 'conventional' languages. Putting that aside I do believe it is a language easy for people with little related experience to learn, so it is an advantage especially if you are from SBMT and wish to learn VBA for practical purposes.

MT covers Excel and a small part of VBA; final covers the rest of VBA
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think the teaching is quite decent, comparable to your secondary school teacher perhaps? I believe people also find Prof. Horner to be more interesting (or funny) although I cannot be sure as I have never 'sit' in his lectures.

I am actually not very sure what to comment as I skipped most of the lessons after midterm. Usually, reading the powerpoints should be enough as they are quite detailed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs (20%) are the easiest part as you can call TAs to mark your lab during lab sessions. They will tell you which part you have done wrong so that you can correct it and tell them to mark it again. This means that you will virtually always get 100% in every lab.
You can hand in via Canvas in case you woke up late and did not go to the lab session, in fact I believe this is the only way you can get an imperfect score other than not handing in it at all LOL

MT (30%) and Final (50%) are of the same nature in which the questions may deliberately trick you, but not as tricky compared to COMP1022P (the Java course). Since it is open book and open notes, many people bring their textbook and printed lab codes to the exam.

For me:
Lab 100% MT 98% Final 96% -> A+
Mean is ~75% for both MT and Final
reviews.comment_workload:
Labs are generally easy to do, just that you may need to follow all the procedures which can be quite repetitive.

There are 8 labs in total and only 4 of them is marked. Attendance is not taken so you can safely not attend the unmarked labs. However, some of them is a continuation of previous labs, so in case you did not attend a unmarked lab you may have to complete it afterwards somewhere else before moving on to the subsequent marked lab.

There is quite an amount of content to be studied for MT and exam but the good news is you do not need to remember any of them as again the exams are open-book.

reviews.author: sps
reviews.comment_content: The course teaches Excel formulas and VBA application on Excel. The content is not difficult for students who have basic junior secondary computer training, plus each topic is demonstrated with various daily life examples.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturer can explain concepts with the aid of, but not merely rely on, the lecture notes. Lesson is enjoyable as the lecturer presents in a dramatic way and tell jokes occasionally. Besides, the tutors are compatible to address student's queries and give clear instructions during the lab session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Exam tests whether student can apply learned rather than memorizing all the formulas thus it is more important to understand the concepts and examples. Some questions are similar to the appeared in lecture notes.
It is not difficult to attain full mark for lab projects with the given lab manual.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is relatively lighter than some common core courses such as HUMA1000. There are only two exams and weekly-lab projects which usually can be completed within the assigned lab session.

reviews.author: etkf
reviews.comment_content:
The course started with some basics in Excel such as the formulae, which most university students should know since they are so important and useful, no matter whether you are from engineering, science or even business school.
Then VBA was introduced, a friendly programming language. The concepts are not very hard, but need some practice in order to master it. Practice makes perfect.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is a very nice professor with impressive teaching skills. He can explain every single concept clearly in a short period of time. I highly suggest to take his class if it is possible to do so.
reviews.comment_grading:
I forgot the grading policy in detail, but in general, there were a few labs, which can be done before the lab sessions, then midterm and final exams.
Overall the grading distribution is pretty good. I got only above mean around 0.5 ~ 0.7 SD in both midterm and final, full mark in labs, and it turned out to be an A, which was quite surprising.
reviews.comment_workload: As mentioned previously, there will be some labs during the course. They are not very difficult but time consuming, so it is highly recommended to finish them before the session, or at least try them out first.

reviews.author: Channing
reviews.title: David Rossiter is the best
reviews.comment_content: This course is designed to equip students with the fundamental concepts of programming using the VBA programming language, within the context of the Microsoft Excel program. Students will first learn how to use Excel to analyze and present data, and will then learn how to use VBA code to build powerful programs.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teaching, very humourous, always asking questions in class which keeps you brainstorming. The questions are good for clearing your concepts. If you can understand every question in class, there is no problem for you in the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading.
reviews.comment_workload: light workload, just some labs and the TAs will help you out.

reviews.author: T.Ting
reviews.title: Good grade and Easy course!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic excel functions that everybody should know.
It is okay not to attend class before mt because only basic stuff are taught. But you should pay attention to the materials of VBA programming. If you cannot manage VBA concepts, then the course will be a holy hell to you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very funny teacher via Zoom. He tells a lot of jokes( some are little dirty but appropriate) that makes atmosphere chill.

I can tell he is really dedicated to teaching, everytime he carefully explains the reasons behind the concept. I am not a engineering student but I had fun in the course.

Gibson's teaching won't let you down.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Grade B+

MT above mean 1 sd
Final reach mean
3 LABs all full mark

i think he gives a very lenient grading on all of us. It is one of the best grade courses in HKUST.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very Light workload.

There are only 3 hand-in labs , 1 midterm and 1 final.

For LABs, the tutor do demonstrations and you just need to follow. Often the only thing you have to do is 4 to 5 lines of coding ( very simple and straight-forward, no worries)

The average time for me to finish one LAB is 1 to 2 hours. The course won't cost you too much time.

reviews.author: ustidiot
reviews.comment_content:
The first part is about excel formulas
The second part is about VBA

reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 94/100
Lab: Full mark
Bonus mark: 0
Final is cancelled
Grade: A
Very hard to get A+. The curve is very high because the content is relatively easy but it is a good course for you to pull up your GPA. Be careful in exams as there are trick questions.
reviews.comment_workload: There are 8 labs, but only 4 is graded. You can get full marks easily if you follow the lab menu carefully.

reviews.author: KYOcean
reviews.title: As you should know already, GPA booster!
reviews.comment_content:
First started with excel formulas and by mid-term student would some basic knowledge of VBA (Mainly creating Loops). After mid-term there would be more content on VBA.
Declaimer : Online course this sem due to pandemic.
reviews.comment_teaching: He spoke fast, nonetheless a super lovely lecturer. Still had a great time attending lectures even though its on zoom.
reviews.comment_grading:
Definitely good grades
However keep in mind that the final exams of this course in spring sem have been getting pretty hard. Therefore, I wouldn't say A range comes with ease and would still need to put in some work.

Mid-term : Carried out online with Canvas. In quite a different format compared to the past as we were able to use excel on our own pc during the exam. To ensure fairness, there was only one ' deduce from the codes' kind of question. And I was only able to take advantage of this situation (able to use excel) for one question. Still, mid-term became easier than past years

Final : Also done in Canvas. Two papers, one hour each with 15 mins break in between. This time we weren't able to copy codes from the questions (They added tricks to the codes hence we could only copy a bunch of useless codes). So they put in variety types of questions (just like finals from the past)  and they were difficult.

Labs work (40%) full mark
Midterm (20%) 100/100  Mean: 76.8   SD:~17
Final (40%) 80/100  Mean: 51.2  SD: 14.8   Highest: 96.7
Grade: A+ (Despite 16 marks lower than the highest in the final...)
No bonus mark for answering questions as Zoom lecture this sem.

I had no CS background,  you don't need it to get good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. Didn't attend any Labs as they were optional. But still shouldn't take a long time to do them on your own.

reviews.comment_grading:
Should be pretty good.
But due to university policy this semester, the final is canceled. Only assignments and mid term is counted. The cut off of the grades thus are high.
There are bonus mark in answering questions, these can be really helpful in achieving higher sub-grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Few easy assignments. Each take less than an hour to be done. Just follow the guidelines.

reviews.author: UST Duke Lam
reviews.title: Special Semester Under Social Unrest
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1-2: Learning Excel Features
-Cell References
-Cell Formulas (including but not limited to: SUM(), AVERAGE(), MAX(), MIN(), RANK(), COUNTIF(), SUMIF(), SUMIF(), LEN(), UPPER(), LOWER(), LEFT(), RIGHT(), SUBSTITITE(), IF(), AND(), OR(), NOT(), VLOOKUP(), HLOOKUP(), ISNA(), IFNA(), ISERROR(), IFERROR(), etc.)

Weeks after: Excel with VBA
-Referring to Cells (Cells(), Range())
-Making decisions (AND, OR etc.)
-Looping (While...Wend, Do While...Loop, For Loop, etc.)
-Making random numbers (Rnd())
-Changing the appearance of cells
-Using excel objects
-Drawing excel shapes
-Types of variable in Excel VBA

As this semester is quite special, there's only a midterm but no final exam. The above is the content for the midterm exam.

The following is the content after the midterm exam. Although not examined in this semester, here are the contents for your reference:

-More on Loops
-Using shapes as buttons
-Different ways to make a macro
-Subroutines and functions
-More on variables
-Basic GUI controls
-RGB representation
-Arrays

The content is quite useful, especially if you are from business school. However, if you wish to major in IS, you are not recommended to enroll in this course as you have to take ISOM 3400 instead of ISOM 3230 as ISOM 3230 has an exclusion of COMP 1022Q. ISOM 3230 would have a more comprehensive look on the business analytics side of excel, while COMP 1022Q looks at more of the technical side of excel and VBA. ISOM 3400 is a Python course, which is considerably harder than excel VBA.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. David Rossiter is very nice and funny in class. He is energetic, and always tell jokes in hopes of initiating the class atmosphere.

He is responsive to emails. It is easy to find him and approach him to ask questions after class and through email.

He won't pick people who raise their hands in lectures to answer the lecture bonus questions! He picks randomly from the crowd. Wearing clothes with bright colours, bring a cup of coffee or but a water bottle on the table would increase the chance that you get picked in class for that sweet 0.5%!
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading very lenient.

[Special grading scheme for this semester]
One grading scheme only

Each lab work: 16.67%
4 labs = 66.68%
Lab 3: 100/100, Mean=98.6, SD=7.0
Lab 5: 100/100, Mean=96.8, SD=10.4
Lab 6: 100/100, Mean=96.4, SD=8.7
Lab 8: 100/100, Mean=98.4, SD=6.2

Midterm: 33.32%
95/100
Mean=76.2, SD=15.7, Max=100, Min=20 (excluding zeros)

Lecture Bonus
Each question answered in class + 0.5% on top of the final grade
7 questions answered (+3.5%)
Mean=2.14 (+1.07%), Max=12 (+6%)

Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Very very light workload. Just revised 2 hours before the midterm and got more than 1sd above the mean score. You could attend the lab sessions to copy the code that is demonstrated by Peter (the TA). There's nothing else really. The workload matches with a 1000-level 3 credit course. This is easily the best grade common core with the least workload in UST.

reviews.author: Bilibala
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
His style is quite entertaining but he speaks too quick, which makes it hard for students who know nothing about VBA to catch up during lessons.

Some people told me that Cecia teaches better. She speaks slower, step by step so her way of teaching might be suitable for students who start from zero. Plus, she knows Cantonese so you may ask her fluently after lessons if you don't understand the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Personally find 2017-18 final exam is much more easier.
2018-19 Fall sem final exam tests 0% about excel (which claims to be 20% of course materials), all are about VBA.

So you either get it right and get all 7 to 10 marks for each questions or you get almost 0 in final exam.
That is why the score result ranged from 0 to 100.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light.
You can skip all the lectures.
No homework/ assignment.
You only have to hand in your lab work (approx. once every two weeks). You may even skip the lab if you know how to do it by yourself.
Optional midterm exam.
Compulsory Final exam only.

reviews.author: SidneySeo
reviews.title: The best
reviews.comment_content:
This class especially, VBA is very interesting at the moment  as I have not finished this course haha.
Students who likes to solve logical problems will like the course for sure.

As I am not a student with CS-related background, this is my only COMP course in my u life. I would say it is a relatively simple course, easy to understand, train more on your thinking skills rather than memorising things.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am in Gibson class. He is a funny guy, but I think he talked a little bit fast, I could not catch up with his pace (it may be my problem)

Thanks to the online lectures, I can join other lecturers' section. From then, I started attending Cecia's class. I really enjoy her class, she is very patient and so nice. She may include some warm up exercise to help us review the previous lecture content. In general, I really like her teaching. I think her class is very suitable for students who may need more time to digest the concepts.

Also, Peter, our TA, is very nice too. He is delivering the lab content very clearly. and I rmb I emailed him for enquiries, then he replied me at 6am the other day. very responsive and helpful!
reviews.comment_grading:

for exam, usually exam is more difficult than the practice tests and review questions.

reviews.author: vtsui
reviews.comment_content:
Non-VBA Excel Functions (week 1-3)
Cell References, Operators (^ power, <> not equal to), Logic Functions (and, or, not),String Functions (Concatenation, LEN) IF, VLOOKUP, HLOOKUP, LookUp Error

VBA (week 3-12)
Macro, VBA Event, InputBox & MsgBox
Cell References (Cells(Row, Column), ActiveCell - currently selected cell)
IF...Then, Else IF, COUNTIF
Types of Variable (Integer, Long, Single , Double, Boolean)
Loop (While...Wend; Do While...Loop; Do...Loop While, For Loops, (For...To...(Step)...Next),  For Each Loop (For Each...In...Next)
Specifying Input and Output Type, Random Numbers, RANDBETWEEN(a,b)
Local & Global Variables, Excel Objects (Range = cells, Shape), Excel Color (RGB), Doing VBA Events (.Rows.Count, .Value), Brackets for functions with input parameters and output, Private and Public Functions, GUI Control
Object-Oriented Programming (class, attributes, method)
Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is good and easy understand.
Using Zoom, he will also answer our questions typed in chat box.

If you send email to ask, he may also answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Maybe due to the online examination, the final is too difficult. There are two papers in final. Both are 90 total in marks.
Mean: 30+ /90
It really shows the difficulties of exam.

The midterm is easy.

The content and VBA is easy in understanding compared with other Comp course so many people get high marks in examinations.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are around 3 to 4 labs that needed to hand in and other do not.

not too many workload

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: Good grade course but suits students with IT talents
reviews.comment_content: To be honest, before i get started writing on this review, i must warn you guys that COMP1022Q is not as good grade as you think. If u have gifted talents in CS,u will definitely do well in this course. But if u are a computer idiot(like me), DO NOT take this course or ur GPA will be spoiled. Actually I got A in other courses but for this so-called "靚grade course", I got an appalling B- grade at the end. Therefore, DO NOT take this course  WITHOUT any thorough consideration. Despite excel being easy, the codes in VBA can go insane in the final exam. So, i just sit there in the exam with arm folded 😢
